variant.question: When the opinions of members of society in a high power distance culture contradict those of their superiors, they..

options.text: are unlikely to speak out.
are required to speak out.
will be asked to speak out.
are likely to speak out.

variant.question: The impression of an apparent movement of light when stared at for a relatively long period of time in the dark is called

options.text: autokinesis
white out
oculografic illusion
oculogyral illusion

variant.question: How may haze effect perception?

options.text: Objects seem to be further away than in reality.
Haze makes the eyes to focus at infinity
There will be better contrast between objects
Objects seem to be closer than in reality.

variant.question: An illusion of obtaining greater height above ground can occur when:

options.text: suddenly flying over small trees after prolonged flying over tall trees.
decelerating at low altitude.
accelerating at low altitude.
flying over high terrain in low visibility.

variant.question: Perceptional illusions are

options.text: normal and can be prevented by trusting instrument read-out.
usually not serious except in bad weather.
never caused by the brain’s ability to distort normal sense inputs.
abnormal and indicate weakness in one or more of the senses.

variant.question: Which of the following is most true?

options.text: Regular exercise is beneficial to general health, but the most efficient way to lose weight is by reducing caloric consumption.
Regular exercise is beneficial to general health, and is the only effective way to lose weight.
Regular exercise and reduction in caloric consumption are both essential in order to lose weight.
Regular exercise is an impediment to losing weight since it increases the metabolic rate.

variant.question: Select the correct statement from the ones below.

options.text: Smoking reduces the capacity of the cariovascular system to transport oxygen.
Smoking is unhealthy because nicotine causes many forms of cancer.
Smoking is a risk factor only for lung cancer.
Smoking causes addiction because of the carbon monoxide contained in the smoke.

variant.question: Select the correct statement from the ones below.

options.text: The harmful effects of smoking are also detected in parts of the body other than the lungs (e.g. bladder, kidneys and blood vessels).
Low blood pressure is associated with smoking.
If someone has smoked for more than 20 years, the beneficial health effects of stopping smoking are negligible.
Addiction to nicotine does not develop if someone has been smoking for less than half a year.

variant.question: Select the correct statement from the ones below.

options.text: Smoking reduces the capacity of the cardiovascular system to transport oxygen.
Smoking is unhealthy because nicotine causes many forms of cancer.
Smoking is a risk factor only for lung cancer.
Smoking causes addiction because of the carbon monoxide contained in the smoke.

variant.question: Autokinetic illusion is:

options.text: an illusion in which a stationary point of light, if stared at for several seconds in the dark, may - without a frame of reference - appear to move.
the sensation during a radial acceleration of seeing a fixed reference point moving into the opposite direction of the acceleration.
poor interpretation of the surrounding world.
a conflict between the visual system and bodily sensations.

variant.question: Nerve conduction is an electrochemical process, hence it is..

options.text: caused by the movements of electrically-charged molecules.
faster if the voltage level increases (e.g. during sport).
produced by electrons flowing through the nerve like an electric current.
susceptible to induction by external magnetic fields.

variant.question: Which are some of the most critical types of perceptual illusions?

options.text: Visual illusion (e.g. blind spots), kinaesthetic illusion (e.g. the leans), and auditory illusion (e.g. missed radio call).
Coriolis illusion (e.g. constant turning), neurological illusion (e.g. after-images), and auditory illusion (e.g. hearing voices).
Haptic illusion (e.g. colour-blind), vestibular illusion (e.g. graveyard spiral), and sensory illusion (e.g. spatial disorientation).
Geometric illusion (e.g. depth perception), somatosensory illusion (e.g. autokinesis), and vestibular illusion (e.g. feeling dizzy).

variant.question: Which of the following statements concerning information is correct?

options.text: 70 to 80 % of information processed by man enters via the visual channel.
The proprioceptive senses (seat-of-the-pants sense) are completely reliable for orientation when flying in IMC.
Hearing is the sense which collects most information in man.
The kinaesthetic channel provides the most important information for flying.

variant.question: Which are the most critical perceptual illusions?

options.text: Visual (blind spots), kinaesthetic (leans) and auditory (missed radio call) illusion
Geometric (depth perception), somatosensory (autokinesis) and vestibular (dizziness) illusion
Coriolis (sensation of constant turning), neurological (after-image) and auditory (hearing voices) illusion
Haptic (colour blindness), vestibular (graveyard spiral) and sensory (spatial disorientation) illusion

variant.question: What impression do you have when outside references are fading away (e.g. fog, darkness, snow and vapour)?

options.text: It is difficult to determine the size and speed of objects.
There is no difference compared with flying on a clear and sunny day.
Objects seem to be closer than in reality.
Objects seem to be much bigger than in reality.

variant.question: Flying above a vast desert area, you can expect to have the impression of...

options.text: being higher than you really are.
turning.
climbing.
flying too fast.

variant.question:
In conditions of reduced visibility such as dust or haze, objects of equal size and distance may be perceived as being larger or smaller than in reality
This illusion is called the

options.text: Top-down illusion
Bottom-up illusion
Interactive illusion
Müller-Lyer illusion

variant.question: With regard to illusions due to perceptive conflicts, it may be said that they:

options.text: are mainly due to a sensory conflict concerning perception of the vertical and the horizontal between the vestibular and the visual system.
originate from a conflict between instrument readings and external visual perceptions.
are caused by the absence of internal visual cues exclusively.
are caused by a conflictual disagreement concerning attitudinal perception between the various members of a crew.

variant.question: Perception is based upon:

options.text: information received as well as past experience and knowledge.
past experience and knowledge only.
solely upon technical ability.
information received only.

variant.question: The "Gestalt laws" formulate:

options.text: basic principles governing how objects are mentally organized and perceived.
basic principles regarding the relationship between motivation and performance.
basic principles governing the relationship between stress and performance.
basic principles governing the effects of habit and experience.

variant.question:
Of the following statements, select those which apply to information.
1) It is said to be random when it is not intended for receivers.
2) It is intended to reduce uncertainty for the receiver.
3) It is measured in bits.
4) Each bit of information reduces uncertainty by a quarter.
The correct statement(s) is (are):

Of the following statements, select those which apply to information.
1) It is said to be random when it is not intended for receivers.
2) It is intended to reduce uncertainty for the receiver.
3) It is measured in bits.
4) Each bit of information reduces uncertainty by a quarter.The correct statement(s) is (are)
From the same distance, smaller objects are usually perceived to be further away than larger objects. What is the reason for this perception?

options.text: Top-down processing
Muller Lyer processing
Interactive processing
Bottom-up processing

variant.question: Incorrect perception:

options.text: can be highly persuasive.
will only affect flight deck crew.
can be easily recognized.
will only affect one member of the crew at a time.

variant.question:
What may be the origins of representation errors?
1) Perception errors.
2) The catering for all available information.
3) Incorrect information from the observed world.
4) The receipt of a bad piece of information.

Which of the following characteristics pose the greatest risk for flight safety?
When the behaviour is...

options.text: aggressive, antisocial, or non-conforming.
passive, sociable, or conforming.
passive, sociable, or non-compliant.
sociable, compliant, or impulsive.

variant.question: How can you describe the top down process?

options.text: Comparing data stored in the brain with the new precepted information, critically disguising inconsistent details.
A process for gathering data and distributing it to the different parts of the brain.
A data controlling process for protecting the brain from adding and saving irrelevant data.
Comparing data stored in the brain with the new precepted information, possibly adding missing data.

variant.question: What is the main adverse effect of expectation with regards to perception?

options.text: Expectation often guides the focus of attention towards a particular aspect, while possible alternates are neglected.
Expectation is a tool that allows capture of all relevant information.
Expectations always lead to routine errors.
The attention area is enlarged by expectation.

variant.question: Which of the following provides the basis of all perceptions?

options.text: The intensity of the stimuli.
The aural or visual significance attributed in short term memory.
The separation of figure and background.
The aural or visual significance attributed in long term memory.

variant.question: Stereotypes are preconceptions or prejudices which can lead us to

options.text: mis-judge individuals even if we have contact with them.
act in the same manner in all situations and thus assuring stability.
develop better teamwork by standardizing procedures.
communicate non-verbally with a stranger.

variant.question: Conscious perception:

options.text: is a mental process involving experience and expectations.
involves the transfer of information from the receptor to the brain only.
relies upon the development of intuition.
relates to the correct recognition of colours.

variant.question: Judgment is based upon:

options.text: a process involving a pilot's attitude to take and to evaluate risks by assessing the situation and making decisions based upon knowledge, skill and experience.
the development of skills from constant practice of flight manoeuvres.
the ability to interpret the flight instruments.
a decision making process involving physical sensations and their transfer to manually operate the aircraft controls.

variant.question: The most dangerous characteristic of perception is, that it

options.text: is extremely resistant to correction.
will only occur under conditions of stress.
can easily be changed.
will mainly occur under conditions of relaxation.

variant.question: The first stage in the information process is:

options.text: sensory stimulation.
perception.
the recognition of information.
selective attention.

variant.question: Which of the following is correct?

options.text: 70 % ? 80 % of information processed by humans enters the visual channel.
Kinaesthetic perception is the most important channel in flying.
Flying by the 'seat-of-the-pants? sense is completely reliable when in IMC or with a poor visual horizon.
Hearing is the most important sense for humans.

variant.question: Perceiving a small object as further away or a larger object as being closer is an example of:

options.text: Top down processing
Interactive processing
Myler's perspective
Bottom up processing

variant.question: Which option correctly lists, for pilots, the three most critical types of perceptual illusion and corresponding examples?

options.text: Visual illusion (blind spots), kinaesthetic illusion (having the leans), and auditory illusion (missed radio call).
Coriolis illusion (constant turning), neurological illusion (after-images) and auditory illusion (hearing voices).
Geometric illusion (depth perception), somatosensory illusions (autokinesis), and vestibular illusion (feeling dizzy).
Haptic illusion (colour-blind), vestibular illusion (graveyard spiral), and sensory illusion (spatial disorientation).

variant.question: Which option correctly lists, for pilots, the three most critical types of perceptual illusion and corresponding examples?

options.text: Visual illusion (blind spots), kinaesthetic illusion (having the leans), and auditory illusion (missed radio call).
Geometric illusion (depth perception), somatosensory illusions (autokinesis), and vestibular illusion (feeling dizzy).
Coriolis illusion (constant turning), neurological illusion (after-images), and auditory illusion (hearing voices).
